raw_text:
Lib Dems 'to target stamp duty'
 
 The Liberal Democrats are promising to raise the stamp duty threshold if they win the general election, in a bid to court first-time house buyers.
 
 Vince Cable, the party's Treasury spokesman, said raising the threshold to £150,000 would prevent over 400,000 home-buyers from paying the tax. He said first-time buyers were being "squeezed out" of the housing market. The Labour party said the Liberal Democrats needed to explain how they would pay for the plan. The plan forms part of a wider Lib Dems policy to encourage first time buyers and those on lower incomes into the market.
 
 Under the proposals, the average saving for a new buyer would be more than £1,000, according to Mr Cable. "First time buyers are being squeezed out of the housing market not only by higher house prices but also by being swept into the stamp duty net," he said. "By failing to uprate the stamp duty threshold Gordon Brown has hit first time buyers and those on low incomes the hardest. "By pledging to increase the threshold to £150,000, the Liberal Democrats will make it possible for many first time buyers to buy a property without facing this tax." Paul Boateng MP, Labour's Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said: "The Lib Dems' sums don't add up. "They can have no credibility until they can say how they would fund their ever growing list of tax and spending commitments." Mr Cable will publish his "Alternative Budget" on Monday.
llama3.2:1b: Liberal Democrats plan to raise stamp duty threshold to £150,000 to target first-time house buyers, aiming to prevent 400,000 from paying tax.
The party's Treasury spokesman Vince Cable will pledge to uprate the threshold without explaining how they would fund it.

Labour argues that the Liberal Democrats' proposals lack funding details and raises questions about their financial feasibility.

However, Labour argues they must explain how they will pay for the plan, which forms part of a wider policy to encourage new homeownership and support low-income families.
Under their proposal, the average saving for a new buyer would be more than £1, 000 if raised to £150, 000.
However, Labour suggests they can't afford to do so, as they need to explain how they will fund their ever-growing tax and spending commitments.

tinyllama:1.1b: The Liberal Democrats are promising to raise the stamp duty threshold if they win the general election, aimed at encouraging first-time buyers to enter the housing market.
The party's Treasury spokesperson Vinçe Cable announced plans for a "firm tax rate" of £150,000 would reduce the average saving for a new buyer from around £1,300 to about £900, according to Cable.
The Labour Party has criticized the plan, saying that it will only benefit the richest first-time buyers and those on lower incomes, who are facing "swept into the stamp duty net" by house prices.
Labour's Chief Secretary to the Treasury Paul Boateng also denounced the Lib Dems' proposed budget measures, including the planned upgrades to stamp duty, as "nonsense."

According to Treasury spokesman Vince Cable, raising the threshold to £150,000 would prevent over 400,000 home buyers from paying this tax.
However, Labour's Paul Boateng questions whether the party can afford it in light of Brown's policies, which have hit first-time buyers and those on low income hardest.
The Lib Dems plan also includes measures to support the housing market by reducing the number of properties being purchased through a tax on transactions above £300,000.

Labour's Paul Boateng criticized the proposal, questioning how the Liberal Democrats would fund such commitments without raising taxes or cutting other spending.
Cable is set to unveil his "Alternative Budget" on Monday, outlining more of their economic policies designed to support first-time buyers and lower-income individuals.
